title: Department and Title of Minister) Order 2011 (S.I. No. 219 of 2011)), hereby
heading: 4. The Principal Regulations are amended by inserting after Regulation 9
text_raw:
4. The Principal Regulations are amended by inserting after Regulation 9 

the following regulation: 

“Extension of validity of prescription to more than 6 months after date 
specified on prescription 

9A. (1) Subject to paragraphs (3) and (4), a person carrying on a retail 
pharmacy business, the superintendent pharmacist and the supervising 
pharmacist shall ensure that a prescription (other than a prescription 
specifying a period between 6 and 12 months) is not dispensed more than 
6 months after the date specified on the prescription unless a registered 
pharmacist has reviewed the prescription and is satisfied that, having 
regard to the pharmaceutical and therapeutic appropriateness of the 
medicine therapy for the patient including consideration of signs or 
symptoms indicative of a possible adverse reaction, and having engaged 
in dialogue with the patient or the patient’s representative— 

(a) 

the patient has a continuing need or chronic condition that 
justifies dispensing after the expiry of the period of 6 
months, 

(b) 

the patient’s history with the prescribed medicinal product 
has not changed,

than 12 months after the date specified on the prescription. 

(2) Where a prescription is dispensed more than 6 months after the 
date specified on the prescription pursuant to the exemption provided in 
paragraph (1), the registered pharmacist who extended the period for 
dispensing under the prescription shall make reasonable efforts to ensure 
that the person who prescribed the medicinal product, or another relevant 
primary healthcare provider, is informed of the decision to extend within 
the period of 7 days following the decision. 

(3) A prescription shall not be dispensed, in accordance with the 
exemption in paragraph (1), more than 6 months after the date specified 
on the prescription where— 

(a) 

(b) 

the prescriber has indicated that the medicinal product 
concerned is not to be so dispensed by using the words 
“do not extend” on the prescription, or 

the medicinal product concerned is a controlled drug 
specified in Schedule 2, 3 or 4 to the Misuse of Drugs 
Regulations 2017 (S.I. No. 173 of 2017). 

(4) Notwithstanding paragraph (1), a prescription may be dispensed 
in the period between 6 and 9 months from the date specified on the 
prescription, without complying with the provisions of that paragraph, 
where the date specified is before 1 March 2024.” 

GIVEN under my Official Seal, 

29 February, 2024. 

STEPHEN DONNELLY, 
Minister for Health.

EXPLANATORY NOTE 

(This note is not part of the Instrument and does not purport to be a legal 
interpretation.) 

These Regulations amend the Regulation of Retail Pharmacy Businesses 
Regulations 2008. 

The purpose of these Regulations is to allow for the dispensing of prescriptions 
up to 12 months from the date of the prescription in certain circumstances. 

These Regulations may be cited as the Regulation of Retail Pharmacy 
Businesses (Amendment) Regulations 2024.
